author: Jonathan Walker
title: What does the future hold for Chi Onwurah after she broke Jeremy Corbyn's three-line whip?
text:
Get daily   
A North East MP who voted against leaving the European Union said she couldn’t support a “Donald Trump-style” Brexit which would damage the North East. 
Chi Onwurah, MP for Newcastle Central, was one of 52 Labour MPs to vote against the Government’s European Union (Notification of Withdrawal) Bill on Wednesday night. 
It came a week after she voted in favour of the Bill, which allows Prime Minister Theresa May to trigger Article 50 and begin the process of leaving the European Union. But the initial vote was followed by discussion of a series of amendments, which were all rejected. MP Chi Onwurah 
Ms Onwurah said: “We had a week’s debate and no amendments were accepted. That included amendments about protecting the NHS, staying in the single market, protecting our economic and social model so we don’t become a off-shore Trump-style tax haven. 
“Once they were rejected, it was clear May’s Brexit is a Tory Brexit and I couldn’t vote for that. We know that what the Tories do when they get the chance is undermine jobs and livelihoods in the North East, and their Brexit will be no different.” 
The MP is a shadow business minister. 
It is unclear whether she will be allowed to continue in this role after disobeying a “three line whip”, strict orders from the party leader to vote for the legislation. Catherine McKinnell 
Newcastle North MP Catherine McKinnell also voted against the Bill. She said that she would now continue to push the Government to consult English regions including the North East as Brexit negotiations take place. 
The Bill will now go to the House of Lords to be debated. 
One former Minister, Conservative MP Oliver Letwin, said that the Lords could be abolished if it tries to block Brexit. 
Speaking in the Commons, he asked a Government Minister if there would be a chance to debate “the possibility of either the abolition or full scale reform of the Lords” if they attempted to prevent Mrs May triggering Article 50 by the end of March as planned. EU and Union flags (Photo: PA) 
Labour leader Jeremy Corbyn faces criticism after ordering his MPs to vote in favour of the Brexit Bill. SNP leader Nicola Sturgeon called him “utterly pathetic” and accused Labour of handing the Prime Minister a “blank cheque” over Brexit. 
But many Labour politicians argue the party had to accept the result of last year’s EU referendum, when the public voted to leave the EU. Read More 
Mr Corbyn said: “Labour has demonstrated that we respect the result of the referendum by voting to begin negotiations to leave the EU, with the overwhelming majority of Labour MPs supporting our party’s position. 
“In recent weeks, Labour has forced the government to reveal what their plan for Brexit actually is. Labour Party leader Jeremy Corbyn 
“Both from their public statements and the amendments their MPs have voted down, the Conservatives have made clear they are determined to use Brexit to turn Britain into a bargain basement tax haven. 
“Labour has a profoundly different vision for our country, with a plan to rebuild and transform Britain so that no one and no community is left behind. 
“Article 50 is just the start of the negotiating process. Labour will be using every opportunity, both in Parliament and in the country, to protect jobs, rights and living standards, and achieve the best possible deal for Britain.” 
Italy’s Prime Minister said Brexit negotiations “will not be easy” but the process must not become “destructive”, after he met Mrs May in 10 Downing Street. Prime Minister Theresa May greets Italian Prime Minister Paolo Gentiloni (Photo: Stefan Rousseau/PA Wire) 
Paolo Gentiloni said his country would take a “constructive and friendly” approach to the divorce. 
He said: “We are aware of the fact that negotiations will not be easy and we also know, and this will certainly be the Italian attitude, that we need a constructive and friendly approach. 
“There is absolutely no point in having a destructive negotiation between the EU and the UK. Read More 
“So, obviously we will do this in the hope of fostering the unity of the 27 countries because without the unity of the 27 countries, it will be difficult to come to some agreement. 
“We must ensure this unity will result in the best possible agreement with the UK.” 
Mrs May underlined plans to make guaranteeing the status of EU nationals living in the UK and those of Britons living in the rest of the bloc a top priority once talks finally begin. 
She said: “I think there is goodwill on all sides in relation to this matter. We recognise people want reassurance for their future.” Like us on Facebook
